Moody's expects to conclude the review in March 2016, after incorporating SCB's efforts to turn around SCBK's performance, as well as the detailed results of SCBK's parent, Standard Chartered Bank's (SCB, FC deposits Aa2 rating under review for downgrade, BCA a2 rating under review for downgrade) performance for 2015.

These results will be available in late February.

Moody's had originally placed the long-term ratings of SCBK on review on 9 November 2015. Please refer to "Moody's reviews for downgrade Standard Chartered Bank Korea's ratings" published on 9 November 2015.

Moody's notes that SCB is restructuring its poorly performing Korean retail and commercial banking businesses, introducing some uncertainty as to the future of SCBK's operations.

The ratings review of SCBK will consider whether: (1) these initiatives have the potential to change SCBK's stand-alone credit profile, as expressed by its BCA; and/or (2) to change the strategic importance of SCBK to SCB and therefore potentially to affect the strength of support from SCB.

11:15 am
BE

StanChart's plan calls for a third of RWAs to be re-priced or re-allocated. The loan book
is over-exposed to a number of higher-risk industries. Shifting to the intended business
model suggests a further revenue decline, in our view calling the US$17.0-17.5bn
income target for 2018 into question. 3Q15 revenues were already weak at US$14.7bn
annualised. We believe much work remains; and that it is problematic for the strategy
that two key areas for investment – Transaction Banking and Wealth – also look set to
contract in 2016.

BE

(UBS.)

BE

Comments by CEO Bill Winters support the view that StanChart grew
too quickly in lending to higher-risk industries and remained overexposed to single
conglomerate counterparties, often demanding too little spread in return. Our analysis
of 19 past credit cycles suggests this one should turn in 2017, but we think StanChart
will likely bear higher losses near term than might ordinarily be expected. We forecast
~150bps loan-loss charges in 2016 and 2017, but visibility is poor and downside risks
predominate.

11:16 am
BE

We are cutting our EPS estimates by 4-10% over 2016-19. This leaves StanChart
trading at 0.55x TNAV for a 2017 and 2018 forecast ROTE of 5-8%. We think these
valuations look reasonable, despite the downside risks we see to near-term estimates.
Our SOTP-derived target price falls to 510p (HK$58.7) from 609p given our lower
estimates and falling peer group multiples. With a target price much in line with current
trading levels and given our view of little yield support, we maintain our Neutral rating.

BE

He has a $1.2bn loss for 2016 in for 2016.

PM

ouch

11:17 am
BE

And you have to say, there aren't many reasons to pay more than 0.55x TNAV for a structurally shambolic, legacy burdened bank that has no clear path back to profitability.

BE

New regulation would affect new sales of AIA and Prudential but
might not be significant in near term. The new regulation would affect
12% of AIA’s total premium which come from onshore mainland contributors.
AIA Hong Kong annualized new premium contributed 29% of total, and
recorded the highest 1H15 growth of +35% yoy among all regions attributable
to sales to mainland policyholder (amounted to 43% of total Hong Kong
premium). The new regulation might reduce AIA Hong Kong premium growth
by 10% (translate to total premium slowdown by 3%) in worst case scenario,
assuming Hong Kong premium grew organically only, benchmarking to FY13,
1H14, FY14 growth of 29%, 23%, 22% respectively when sales to mainlanders
were not popular. In near term, the impact would not be severe as: 1) The new
regulation only restricts the amount of single transaction but does not impose
daily limit for number of total transactions. According to our talk with agents,
policyholders can complete payment for large amount premium by swiping
cards several times. 2) Online payment has not been affected yet.

11:24 am
BE

Yeah. I can get them on a need-to-know basis, though they're rarely NTK when we're talking about grocers and housebuilders.

BE

Today, the ICBC comes into its own.

BE

New regulation would bode well for domestic insurers fundamentally.
Given different mortality, morbidity table and expense loading assumptions,
products in Hong Kong market are relatively favourable than domestic from
fundamental perspective. Inevitably, some policyholders purchase life/health
insurance in Hong Kong. Nevertheless, the volume is negligible. By end of
September 2015, premium incurred overseas was only Rmb21bn accounting for
approximately 1% of total premium in China. Moreover, domestic insurers
target mass market while overseas insurers focus on high net worth individuals.
The new regulation literally would ban some premium outflows and bode well
for domestic insurers.
New regulation triggered fear of further liquidity drain from macro
perspective. Uncertain macro outlook clouds insurance share price
performance, though fundamental stays solid. Regulators have been
working hard to fight against fund outflows. The new measure which applies to
overseas insurance purchase would trigger fear of further liquidity drain. As
Hong Kong listed Chinese insurers are served as A-share proxy (given high beta
and over 15% of investment assets are allocated to A-share equities), A-share
market slump would trigger further share price correction.

11:25 am
BE

Grace Zhou's the analyst there. Just in case you're interested.

PM

Very helpful

BE

More prosaically, Macquarie.

11:26 am
BE

Andy Hughes sent round a note yesterday afternoon that was very helpful. This update is via his HK colleagues.

BE

The big picture: Looking ahead, the key issue is to what extent MCV
business is at risk. It is not clear at this stage how much business is paid for
using bank cards, nor how much of this is above the 5k cap (we presume
most of it). Irrespective of these details, our overriding concern is that this
MCV business is now on Beijing’s radar. HK life companies collected
greater than US$7bn last year from MCVs. It seems clear that SAFE is nervous about
the HK life market as a channel for capital flight from China.

BE

Implications for AIA Group (1299 HK, HK$40.95, Neutral, TP: HK$44.00):
AIA generates 31% of VNB from HK. We understand that AIA’s MCV
business % has historically been above industry average. This implies that
MCVs represent 9-11% of AIA’s VNB. We note that AIA’s average premium
in HK is relatively low at only ~US$3k for RP and ~US$150k for SP (refer p2).
SP contributes 15% to HK ANP. If half of future MCV business were at risk,
this would represent ~5% of VNB. Whilst relatively low (and perhaps
replaceable), the loss of MCVs as a key growth driver would be noticeable at
a time when other growth markets across the region have also slowed. We
forecast VNB growth to slow to 16% this year.

11:27 am
BE

Implications for other companies: We understand AXA (Not Rated) enjoys
the highest proportion of MCV sales, followed by Prudential (PRU LN, £12.18,
Outperform, TP: £15.36, Andy Hughes) stated at 55% of HK sales

BE

So there we go. Pru rallies.

BE

TP cut materially to reflect reduced international option value as we now forecast
a much slower build in international partner sales (of £700m by 23/24). This option value is
extremely sensitive to fee assumptions (5% vs. JEFe at 2% would see option value increase
from £530m to £1.25bn). Whilst the opportunity to blue-sky is fairly unlimited on this front,
the decade-long cashflow history of Ocado UK does not lend itself to a particularly bullish,
DCF-derived domestic fair value. Here, perhaps generously, we assume EBITDA margin build
to 8.5%, continued gradual share gains and capex/sales at maturity of 3.1% (vs. 4% sales
growth to perpetuity). This in itself justifies an equity worth of 180p.

BE

Deutsche ............

11:34 am
BE

FY results show little evidence of profitability at the underlying retail business.
It could be unfortunate timing, as a disruptor in investment phase meets an
industry in gross margin decline, but investors are right to be cautious.
Maintain Hold on balanced risk/reward

BE

Barclays ............

BE

Given that the Ocado share price seems to be highly dependent on perceived prospects of signing an international deal - and the fact that we already knew sales and net debt - today's statement and presentation will have been scrutinised principally for any additional colour on the likelihood and timing of a first overseas agreement. Talk of “multiple deals in multiple territories” still seems very confident, but the withdrawal of any guidance on timing seems less so. (While we can understand why giving a time deadline brings certain pressures, it does beg the question of why a timeline was issued a year ago.) The investment case is somewhat binary in the sense that without any international deals then Ocado looks expensive and potentially strategically weak, but its valuation could suddenly look more attractive and the company strategically very smart the moment a deal is signed. Although it is clear that international food retailers do have options other than Ocado (eg Instacart, Amazon), we are sympathetic to Ocado's point that it is offering a more comprehensive proposition that would allow the partner to keep control of the customer relationship. This remains a difficult story to analyse - but we tend to be less cynical than some in our belief that a deal may be done in 2016 that could significantly boost sentiment.

11:35 am
BE

BE

PM

PM

Casino is anything but a boring supermarket story. Faced with increasing price competition in its native France a number of years ago, Casino decided to lever its balance sheet to acquire assets in emerging market countries, namely Brazil, Thailand, Columbia and Vietnam. Whilst this initially bought the company top-line growth, the combination of Euro denominated debt with emerging market earnings has now become problematic given the deterioration in emerging market macro conditions, currency headwinds, and increasing competition in local markets. Moreover, a deeper examination of its accounting practices and complex holding company structures presents further questions around the ability of Casino and in particularly Rallye - the holding company of CEO Jean-Charles Naouri - to sustainably service its debt.

11:46 am
BE

1) The ChemChina deal will keep Syngenta mgmt
in place to run the company and after the deal a 10-member board led by Mr. Ren
Jianxin, Chairmain of ChemChina, will be created. We think the equity portion of
the Monsanto (MON US, US$87.36, Outperform, TP: US$115.00) bid for SYNN
that was pulled in August (instead of an all cash transaction) and the likelihood for
significant mgmt shake-up was a key to Syngenta turning its back to the MON
offer (though it was at a similar level). In our view, MON investors will be relieved
on the whole that SYNN deal is likely off the table. We do not see an over-the-top
bid as feasible or likely;

BE

2) Market conditions in Ag remain broadly weak – we do
not anticipate a quick fix to the current depressed farmer spending setting in the
near-to-medium term and suspect that the company will make-up ground in crop
protection where the seeds business profit support is lacking; And 3) we think the
CHF480 take-out offer will be accepted by shareholders. In our view, the
ChemChina premium offer is unlikely to be met in all-cash by others.

BE

We've slightly ignored this deal, in truth. So here's a linkfest to make up for all the stuff we haven't written.

Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 152.49, down 0.507 (-0.33%), High: 153.50, Low: 150.50, Volume: 7.81m
BE

So .............. I'm not entirely clear why Sainsbury's gone public this morning with how clever it's being.

11:50 am
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 246.50, down 4 (-1.60%), High: 250.40, Low: 246.40, Volume: 2.77m
BE

It doesn't seem to have helped the share price.

BE

So basically, we have the FD on the tape this morning explaining the mechanics of the stealth share issue by which they're going to buy Argos.

11:52 am
BE

He's very clever, the FD. And it's a clever structure, financially if not operationally.

BE

Largely, it's as we talked about on the day of the deal: http://ftalphavill...ense-of-argosbury/

BE

As in, you transfer the loan book to Sainsbury Bank and "receive" £600m.

11:54 am
BE

Chuck in £100m to bump up the CET1 ratio.

BE

But you also get £250m cash from the HRG balance sheet.

PM

Feels very uncomfortable, a grocer using its own bank to effectively finance its acquisitions

11:55 am
BE

Yup. So then you give £440m cash back to HOME shareholders, giving yourself a net gain of £300m.

BE

That net gain is largely paid for by your own shareholders, in equity.

PM

If a Ukrainian company was doing this we'd be shouting about toxicity

11:56 am
BE

We've mentioned throughout that it's the FD's deal. This is a deal put together by and FD. It's risky strategically and tricksy financially.

BE

Here's HSBC.

BE

Intuitively it seems odd that gearing can be reduced by an asset transfer between divisions in the same group, but it makes sense given how banks work. Sainsbury Bank has excess liquidity as it has attracted deposits without matching a loan book on the other side of the balance sheet. The loan book itself has no direct funding to support so we think it makes sense to put these together. Effectively the transaction swaps low yield liquid assets for higher yielding loans. We also believe Sainsbury is eligible for the Bank of England's FLE scheme so can borrow at almost 0% interest if it needs to. As explained above, this swap releases cash and the deal financing should be earnings enhancing. Gearing is reduced as the Group's definition of net debt excludes Sainsbury Bank's own net debt balances.

11:57 am
BE

Ultimately it is about retail: The financing might look value enhancing, but we ultimately believe this is about two challenged retailers getting together and the success will depend on how these challenges are addressed. We do not believe Argos will solve Sainsbury's strategic problems.

BE

Should also note that SocGen doesn't like. Doesn't like at all.

BE

Following the announcement of an offer for Home Retail Group, we downgrade
J Sainsbury from Buy to Hold for the following reasons: 1) The timing is inappropriate in our
view. As highlighted in our recent report “Key trend review II: Where are we in the cycle?”, UK
food retailing still faces challenging market conditions and strong deflation. Although
Sainsbury is doing a good job, it would have been better to remain focused on the core
business in the short term; 2) Loss of pure-player status. J Sainsbury will lose its pureplayer
status. 3) Synergies: reality different from the theory? Management appeared very
confident on the potential level of synergies (‘at least £120m in year 3’). However, a big
proportion (50%, we estimate) is linked to additional revenues (new Argos concessions in
Sainsbury's stores, clothing or leisure ranges from Sainsbury's at Argos), but by definition,
customer behaviour is always difficult to predict. As such, visibility is limited. In a blue-sky
scenario (£120m of synergies), we calculate the accretive impact on EPS would be c.12%,
but it is too early to factor this into our model.

11:58 am
BE

Such a deal should increase the group's risk profile (stronger exposure to nonfood,
stronger exposure to the threat of Amazon). Although we understand the rationale of
the deal on a medium-term view (acceleration of the multi-channel strategy, rationalisation
of selling space), the timing does not look appropriate to us, and the equity story has
significantly changed.

BE

We cut our TP from 310p to 260p due to the increased risk
profile and lower visibility. Our new TP is based on a peer comparison (255p vs 308p, 35%
2016-17e P/E discount to European food retailing sector, vs a 20% discount previously)
and a DCF of 265p vs 312p, assuming WACC 8.6% vs 8.5%, perp. growth 1.5% ,
normalised EBIT margin 3.0% vs 3.2% as of 2022-23e). In a blue-sky scenario and all else
being equal, we estimate that potential value creation linked to the targeted £120m of
synergies may stand at 20%, but we think it is premature to take this into account.

12:03 pm
BE

We last wrote about this here, I think: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3yuXCiVjm

BE

Anyway, Neil Campling at Aviate's more open minded than you.

BE

(Unsurprisingly.)

12:03 pm
BE

Here's an extract of his morning email:

BE

This morning's deal of ChemChina buying Syngenta for more than $43bn in the largest acquisition by a Chinese firm is a real sign of China climbing the value chain. We have written extensively on China internalizing R&D and climbing the value chain. This is happening and in many instances it is being misinterpreted as slowing domestic demand (as it is softening import numbers). China is moving up the value curve in semis, internalising the industry and changing the dynamic from an import led to export led industry. A change from research and academia to a business approach began just last year following the “Guideline of the National IC Industry Development Promotion Framework” policy framework to the State Council. Much of this policy is in reaction to the simple fact worldwide semiconductor consumption has increasingly moved to China. In fact, China semiconductor consumption has risen from 18% in 2003 to

56% last year. In H1 2015 Chinese IC imports amounted to $104bn, whereas export value amounted to $29bn. The current Development of Science and Technology to 2020 plan is to get the export ratio to 30% by 2020. It remains stubbornly at ~20% today. ARM would be the jewel in the crown for enabling such ambition.

BE

With the increasing scarcity of IP, the increasing value of Arm’s technology can’t be overstated. And remember ARM now signs more embedded device licenses (think Vehicles, smart cards, embedded computing etc.) than smartphones. Now the non-believers will say China won’t be allowed to acquire this technology gatekeeper of key IP. Well, for one, UK takeover code is about as robust as the UK border agency service. Second, many expected the US CFIUS (Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States) to block semiconductor M&A last year but the body approved the Chinese takeover of Omnivision, to name just one example, suggests otherwise. Third, ARM licenses its IP to hundreds of companies. Change of ownership would NOT change this licensing arrangement. It would merely enable China to scale the IP and semiconductor technology curve. And of course ARM would not only be of interest to China (refer previous comments on Qualcomm).

11:33 am
BE

mgmt. provided few explanations for the change
of tone, besides confirming that some counterparties may be more attracted to the shorter
lead times and low capex requirements offered by alternative models. What is clear is that
licence deals are unlikely to be cashflow +ve from day one, as OCDO noted that not all of
its investment requirements would be recovered though upfront payments from partners.
Mgmt refused to comment on the specific licence fee it is targeting, but we suspect it is
much higher than the 2% we currently model.
